page.title: 16Hall Farm, Bridgham
page.content:
Bridgham Hall Farm lies at the western end of The Street and was built in the early years of this century, to replace the original farmhouse, destroyed by fire. Farm outbuildings lie on both sides of the road, those on the south side adjoining the churchyard. A special attraction are the hens, Muscovy ducks and a peacock, which inhabit the roadside outbuildings.
The farm lands total 309 acres, divided into 3 arable parcels and 6 meadows. The arable land is cropped mainly to wheat and barley, sugar beet and carrots. The meadows currently maintain only 62 heifers and 4 donkeys. The land is not now farmed independently, but forms part of the lands farmed by Wrights of Brettenham Manor (to the west of Bridgham).
